topic: Provide a report on the media's reaction to the recent Democratic debate between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. The report should cover the debate's winners and losers, and how the candidates performed on key issues, including foreign policy, health care, and criminal justice reform.
questions: What was the general consensus among critics regarding the debate performance of Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders?
What was one of the criticisms made by Lucia Graves about Bernie Sanders' debate performance?
Who did Bernie Sanders claim he would be better than in terms of race relations?
What was the topic on which Hillary Clinton was able to present herself as a deeply knowledgeable candidate, according to Scot Lehigh?
What was the outcome of the debate, according to Chris Cilliza at the Washington Post?
What was one of the areas where both candidates performed well initially, according to Lucia Graves?
What was the criticism made by Matthew Yglesias at Vox about Bernie Sanders' debate performance?
What was one of the topics on which Hillary Clinton attacked Bernie Sanders' plan, and what was her argument against it?
Who was a prominent figure that came under attack from Bernie Sanders during the debate?
What was the assessment of Chris Cilliza regarding Hillary Clinton's debate performance?
report: – After Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders faced off in the first Democratic debate since Sanders' big win in New Hampshire, critics agreed there was one big loser: Henry Kissinger, who came under merciless attack from Bernie Sanders. "I'm proud to say that Henry Kissinger is not my friend," Sanders told Clinton. Here's what people had to say about the candidates' performances: "This was Clinton's best debate of the election," decides Chris Cilliza at the Washington Post. She was "in total control all night" and scored plenty of points against Sanders, he writes, while Sanders stumbled despite an improved command of foreign policy—and will probably regret claiming that he will be better on race relations than President Obama. Clinton didn't score any home runs but she still won, according to Matthew Yglesias at Vox. Nothing happened that would cause Clinton supporters to think twice, he writes, while voters getting a first look at Sanders would not have been impressed: The candidate turned in a "dangerously complacent debate performance" and failed to assuage "doubts about his electability" or add anything new to his critique of Clinton. Scot Lehigh at the Boston Globe also calls the debate for Clinton. She came out on top by "presenting herself as a deeply knowledgeable candidate whose progressive stands are tempered by real-world practicality," he writes. This was the case in her attacks on Sanders' plan for a single-payer health care system, where Clinton stressed that the "focus should be on expanding coverage and care to those who still lack it, rather than starting from scratch and overhauling the entirety of the system." Both candidates "performed well initially in talking about systemic racism and reforming the criminal justice system," but the "calm, cool, and collected" Clinton prevailed, writes Lucia Graves at the Guardian. Sanders, she writes, "was oddly on the defensive despite what has been momentum in his favor, starting out the night more combative than Clinton and wasting his time on petty one-liners." Click for some of the debate's best lines.
response:

On the other hand, Sanders struggled to make an impact during the debate, with many critics accusing him of sounding like a "broken record" and failing to score clean hits on Clinton during the first hour of the debate. This moment was seen as a rare misstep for Clinton, who was otherwise able to navigate the debate with ease. questions: What is the name of the annual festival in Yellville, Arkansas, that involves throwing turkeys from buildings and a plane?
Who is among those who have criticized the Turkey Trot festival as "sick"?
Why are domestic turkeys unable to fly effectively?
What is the maximum distance that wild turkeys can fly?
How many turkeys were found injured and bleeding after being dropped from a plane this year?

report: – No matter how busy the holiday travel season, you're pretty much guaranteed to have a smoother flight than the unfortunate turkeys involved in Arkansas' Turkey Trot. The annual October festival in Yellville sees turkeys hurled from buildings and a plane flying 500 feet above the ground. Disturbed? You're not alone. Tommy Lee is among those to bash the "sick" tradition, reports Arkansas Online. Live Science explains the uproar: Domestic turkeys are bred for flightlessness, their bodies too heavy for their wings to get them off the ground. While their wings can slow a descent, there's no guarantee domestic turkeys will survive falls from great heights. The same is true of wild turkeys, which can only fly short distances. Indeed, two turkeys dropped from a plane last year died on impact. At least four turkeys dropped this year were found injured and bleeding, though they've since found refuge at a New York shelter, where they were named John, Ringo, George, and Paul, per the Fairfield Citizen. The town of Yellville technically stopped throwing turkeys in 1989—continuing the Turkey Trot festival started in 1946 with a dance, race, and parade—but local pilots continue to throw turkeys, per the Citizen and Baxter Bulletin. Despite animal activists' appeals, the FAA says it doesn't have the authority to intervene. "FAA regulations do not specifically prohibit dropping live animals from aircraft, possibly because the authors of the regulation never anticipated that an explicit prohibition would be necessary," a rep tells the Huffington Post, adding, "This does not mean we endorse the practice."

topic: Provide a report on any new scientific findings and research regarding the natural environment of Loch Ness in Scotland, including studies on water levels and the possible effects of the nearby North Sea. The report should include any notable discoveries or observations made through this research.
questions: What was the change in depth of Loch Ness caused by tides from the nearby North Sea?
How did scientists measure the change in depth of Loch Ness?
What did a professor compare Loch Ness to in describing the phenomenon?
Would a person on a boat in the middle of the loch notice the change in depth?
Is this phenomenon unique to Loch Ness or has it been observed in other western European lakes?
What is the potential application of the method used by scientists in this study?
Where did the scientists place the underwater pressure sensors to measure the change in depth?
How does the study suggest that oceans affect the Earth's crust?
What is the humorous explanation for the change in lake level mentioned in the article?
What is the name of the study mentioned in the article?
report: – UK scientists have made a nifty, unprecedented discovery about Scotland's Loch Ness, but prepare to be a little disappointed. They found that tides from the nearby North Sea caused the land underneath the lake to shift ever so slightly, resulting in a change in depth of 0.06 inches at either end, depending on whether the tide was in or out. One professor likened it to a carpenter's bubble level, notes the BBC. "I have described Loch Ness as the largest spirit level in the world," he says. "If you were on a boat in the middle of the loch, you certainly wouldn't notice it," adds another. "But a tide like this has never been observed in a western European lake before." The scientists used underwater pressure sensors at various spots in the lake to get the astonishing accuracy, explains Discovery. The hope is that the method can be used at other lakes to shed more light on how oceans affect the Earth's crust. (The study, here, fails to mention the elephant in the room, but a Fark headline suspects that the lake level changes because Nessie is getting out to towel off.)
response:
Recent studies on the natural environment of Loch Ness in Scotland have revealed new insights into the dynamics of this mysterious lake. According to research conducted by scientists using pressure sensors distributed throughout Loch Ness, the loch's water levels have been found to change in response to the movement of the ground beneath it, caused by the tides on the nearby North Sea. This phenomenon, known as ocean tidal loading, results in the land tilting back and forth, causing the water in the loch to "slosh" accordingly. The researchers were able to detect changes as small as 0.1 mm (0.004 in) in the loch's depth over its 35 km (22 mi) length, demonstrating Loch Ness's accuracy as one of the world's longest and most accurate tiltmeters.

This research has significant implications for our understanding of the natural environment of Loch Ness, highlighting the importance of considering the effects of the nearby North Sea on the loch's water levels. The study's findings also underscore the complex interplay between the Earth's surface and the movement of the oceans, a process that is not yet fully understood. Furthermore, the use of pressure sensors to measure depth changes in Loch Ness may provide a new method for studying similar phenomena in other lakes and water bodies around the world.

One of the most notable discoveries made through this research is the realization that the movement of the ground beneath Loch Ness is so subtle that it cannot be tracked using GPS technology. This highlights the limitations of current monitoring methods and the need for more sophisticated tools to study the complex dynamics of the Earth's surface. The study's findings also suggest that the water levels in Loch Ness may be more sensitive to changes in the surrounding environment than previously thought, and that further research is needed to fully understand the relationships between the loch, the North Sea, and the Earth's surface.

Overall, the research conducted on Loch Ness has provided new insights into the natural environment of this enigmatic lake, and has highlighted the importance of considering the complex interactions between the Earth's surface, the oceans, and the water bodies that they interact with. The study's findings have significant implications for our understanding of the Earth's systems and the need for continued research into the dynamics of the natural environment. As scientists continue to study the natural environment of Loch Ness, they may uncover even more secrets about this mysterious lake and its place in the Earth's systems.

The sensors were able to detect changes as small as 0.1 mm (0.004 in) over the 35 km (22 mi) length of the loch. The measurements may be a first for a European lake with land shifting tides due to ocean tidal loading.
 Scotland's Loch Ness is affected by the movement of the ground beneath it caused by the tides on the nearby North Sea. The motion is so subtle that GPS couldn't even track it. When the tide comes in on the North Sea, 13 kilometers (8 miles) to the east of Loch Ness, the increased pressure on the seafloor deforms the Earth, a process called ocean tidal loading. This process causes the land to tilt back and forth, resulting in a change in the loch's levels. The water in the loch acts like a bowl of water on a wobbly table, sloshing according to the movement of the land it rests upon.

topic: Provide a report on NASA's Voyager 1 spacecraft. The report should cover the current location of the spacecraft, the nature of that location, and its implications for the exploration of the solar system. It should also include information on the spacecraft's future trajectory, including when and how it will power down and any notable events in its expected path.
questions: What is the name of the spacecraft that has entered an area of the solar system that scientists didn't know about?
In what year was the Voyager 1 spacecraft launched?
What term is NASA using to describe the region Voyager 1 has entered?
According to chief scientist Ed Stone, what does the newly discovered region represent?
What changes have Voyager's instruments shown in terms of particles from our solar system and interstellar space?
How long may Voyager 1 stay in the in-between zone before entering interstellar space?
What is expected to happen to Voyager 1 around 2025?
How long will it take Voyager 1 to pass a neighboring star after entering interstellar space?
How long will it take Voyager 1 to approach another star after passing the first one?
What is the significance of the discovery of the "magnetic highway" region in the solar system?
report: – How to best learn about the edge of the solar system? Actually go there. NASA says its Voyager 1 spacecraft—which launched in 1977—has entered an area of the solar system that scientists didn't know about, the AP reports. "We do believe this may be the very last layer between us and interstellar space," says chief scientist Ed Stone. NASA is calling the region a "magnetic highway" where particles from inside the sun's magnetic sphere "zoom out, and higher-energy particles from outside to stream in." Scientists based their conclusion on Voyager's instruments, which show a 1,000-fold decrease in low-energy particles from our solar system and a five-fold jump in high-energy particles from interstellar space, reports Huffington Post. Now Voyager 1 may stay in this in-between zone for two or three years, NASA says. Then comes its future in interstellar space, reports Scientific American: powering down around 2025 and passing a neighboring star in about 40,000 years. After that, it will be billions of years before it approaches another star.
response:
Voyager 1, the longest-serving spacecraft in the history of space exploration, is currently situated in the outer reaches of the heliosphere, a region predicted to be the last layer between the spacecraft and interstellar space. According to the Voyager team, the spacecraft is still inside our solar bubble, as indicated by the direction of the magnetic field lines, which have not changed. The particles zipping in and out of this magnetic highway suggest that Voyager 1 is on the cusp of breaking through to interstellar space, with scientists predicting that this may be just a few months to a couple of years away. This region, characterized by a magnetic field, is a unique environment that offers a glimpse into the outside of our solar bubble, as noted by Edward Stone, Voyager project scientist, who stated, "We believe this is the last leg of our journey to interstellar space".

As Voyager 1 continues its journey, it will eventually exit the heliosphere, marking the beginning of its journey into interstellar space. However, the spacecraft's power reserves are limited, and by 2025, all instruments will have to be turned off. After that, the spacecraft will continue to drift through space, with occasional attempts to ping it, but it will no longer be able to send data. In 40,000 years, Voyager 1 will pass by one of our nearest neighbor stars, and in billions of years, it may reach another star, carrying a piece of human ingenuity into the unknown.

Currently, Voyager 1 is 122 AU from Earth, and its twin, Voyager 2, is about 100 AU away. Scientists predict that Voyager 1 may remain within the heliopause, the outer boundary of the solar system, for another two to three years. However, it's challenging to anticipate how long it will be until the probe leaves the solar system. The future trajectory of Voyager 1 is uncertain, but one thing is clear: it will continue to explore the unknown, carrying with it the legacy of human curiosity and ingenuity.

In conclusion, Voyager 1 is a remarkable spacecraft that has been exploring the outer reaches of our solar system for over 40 years. Its current location in the heliosphere, a region predicted to be the last layer between the spacecraft and interstellar space, marks a significant milestone in its journey. As the spacecraft continues to drift through space, it will eventually exit the heliosphere and enter interstellar space, carrying with it the legacy of human ingenuity into the unknown. The future trajectory of Voyager 1 is uncertain, but one thing is clear: it will continue to explore the unknown, leaving behind a trail of discoveries and a testament to human curiosity.

questions: What was the weather condition on the Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnel when Joseph Chen's truck went over the side?

report: – A blustery day on a Virginia bridge led to a truck driver's death Thursday, the AP reports. Joseph Chen, a 47-year-old employee of Evans Transport, was crossing the Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnel in his tractor-trailer around 12:30pm, shortly after weather reports had indicated a Level 1 wind advisory, meaning winds were clocking in at over 40mph, the Virginian-Pilot reports. The North Carolina man was driving his truck southbound when his vehicle went over the side and into the 45-degree Chesapeake Bay. As his truck began to sink, Chen was spotted standing atop it, offering hope he'd survive the freak accident. But after a Navy chopper pulled him from the water, he died en route to the hospital. Just 30 minutes after Chen's truck was swept off the bridge, the wind advisory was raised to a Level 2, which means winds had crept up past 47mph. Between 1964 and 2011, 10 vehicles driving over that bridge have met similar fates, with only one survivor out of the bunch, per Virginian-Pilot records. A truck driver who crosses the bridge a couple of times a week tells WAVY "on a windy day, you can feel it" and that his truck will sway from left to right, depending on the wind's direction. Meanwhile, Chen's wife, Billie Jo, tells the Virginian-Pilot her husband "was off the chain." They would've marked their 10-year anniversary in April. She added her husband, whom she said was "awesome," had two kids from a previous marriage. (A truck fell from the sky in San Diego.)
response:
A tragic incident occurred on the Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnel (CBBT) on Thursday afternoon, resulting in the loss of life of a 47-year-old tractor-trailer driver, Joseph Chen, of Greenville, North Carolina. Chen was hauling a load of seafood for Evans Transports when his vehicle went over the side of the bridge, causing his death. The incident happened on the southbound side of the CBBT at mile marker 15 around 12:30 p.m.. The Medical Examiner's Office ruled his death as accidental, caused by drowning and hypothermia. Chen's death was a devastating blow to his family, who had lost a loving father and husband. The incident was also a shock to the community, particularly those who knew Chen as the founder and president of the Turn-N-Burn Motorcycle Club.

The accident led to the closure of the bridge on both sides, but it was reopened before 2 p.m.. The bridge officials had issued Level 2 wind restrictions at the time of the incident, with winds exceeding 47 mph. Tractor-trailers like Chen's were required to haul a gross payload of 30,000 pounds, in addition to the weight of the rig, under these restrictions. Truck driver Charles Lattimore from Chesapeake shared his experience of crossing the bridge-tunnel on a windy day, stating that you can feel the wind pushing your trailer and tractor to the left or the right. Lattimore expressed his condolences for the victim and his family, emphasizing the importance of safety on the bridge.

The incident has raised concerns about safety on the CBBT, with the Virginia Trucking Association issuing a statement expressing their condolences and emphasizing the importance of safety. Previous incidents on the bridge have highlighted the risks faced by tractor-trailer drivers, including a January 2016 accident where the driver was rescued and survived, and a May 2014 incident where the driver died. The water temperature at the time of the accident was 45 degrees, with a wave height between five and seven feet. The investigation into the incident is ongoing, with authorities working to determine the cause of the accident.

report: – Six Americans and a Brit have vanished without a trace on the high seas between New Zealand and Australia, aboard the 70-foot vessel the Nina, CNN reports.The crew was last heard from on June 4 while battling rough conditions—68mph gusts and waves as high as 26 feet—about a week after their historic schooner left New Zealand's Bay of Islands. Friends reported the vessel missing on June 14, and the fact that its emergency beacon was never activated gave rescuers hope. But the picture that's forming of the Nina's last known movements sounds less promising. A woman aboard the 85-year-old vessel called a New Zealand meteorologist via satellite phone on June 3, asking him, "The weather's turned nasty, how do we get away from it?" They spoke briefly, with Bob McDavitt advising the group to sail south. The following day he received the following text: "ANY UPDATE 4 NINA? ... EVI." After that, the boat vanished, with two aerial searches turning up nothing. More foreboding details, per the AP: The rescue coordinator says the boat realistically should have arrived in Australia two days ago, and the Nina dealt with some leaking issues earlier this year after a new engine was installed. He expressed "grave concerns" to the Age.
response:
Reports have emerged of seven individuals going missing at sea on the route between New Zealand and Australia in the last two months. One such incident is the disappearance of the American schooner "Nina", which was last heard from on June 4 while sailing from New Zealand to Australia. The vessel, an 85-year-old wooden boat, was reportedly caught in a severe storm with winds gusting up to 110 kilometers per hour and waves of up to 8 meters high. The crew, consisting of seven individuals, including six Americans and a British man, was last known to be in the Tasman Sea, approximately 400 miles northwest of New Zealand. The Nina was equipped with modern tracking and communications devices, but all contact was lost after the crew sent a text message, which was the last known communication from the boat. Maritime New Zealand's Rescue Coordination Centre initiated a search for the vessel on June 14, trying to contact the boat over various radio frequencies and contacting other vessels in the area. However, despite the efforts of rescuers, including an Air Force plane searching the area, no signs of the Nina or its crew have been found. The search efforts have been ongoing for several weeks, with Kevin Banaghan, who is spearheading the search, stating that rescuers are "very concerned for their safety and wellbeing". As the search continues, there are several possible scenarios being considered, including the boat losing communications, drifting off course, or the crew taking to lifeboats. Authorities have identified the skipper of the vessel as American David Dyche, and say there are two other American men and three American women aboard, aged between 17 and 73. Friends of the crew posted messages online indicating that the boat originally left from Panama City, Florida, before making its way to New Zealand. The disappearance of the Nina and its crew has sparked concerns among authorities and the public, with many hoping for a positive outcome.

topic: Write a report on the new guidelines issued by Archbishop Charles Chaput of Philadelphia regarding the Catholic Church's stance on marriage, divorce, and same-sex relationships. The report should cover the key points of the guidelines, including the expectations for divorced and remarried couples, same-sex couples, and unmarried couples, as well as the implications for individuals who do not adhere to these guidelines.
questions: How many US Catholics are estimated to have been remarried without getting their first marriage annulled by the church?
What should divorced couples who have remarried do, according to Archbishop Charles Chaput's new guidelines?
Which groups of people, in addition to divorced couples, are also required to abstain from sex according to the new guidelines?
What is the purpose of the new guidelines released by Archbishop Charles Chaput?
According to the guidelines, what can be a sign of "lacking in maturity" in couples?
What should happen to individuals who go against the guidelines, according to the document?
How do the new guidelines relate to Pope Francis' Joy of Love document?

What is recommended for priests to do with couples who aren't interested in getting married?
What is the potential consequence of same-sex relationships, according to the guidelines?
report: – It just got a whole lot less fun to be a Catholic in Philadelphia. New guidelines released by Archbishop Charles Chaput last Friday say divorced couples who have remarried must permanently abstain from sex, instead living like "brother and sister," the Guardian reports. According to the Philadelphia Inquirer, there are about 4.5 million US Catholics who have been remarried without getting their first marriage annulled by the church. But divorcees aren't the only ones Chaput wants to see living without sex. People in same-sex relationships and straight couples who aren't married must also go sexless. Fortunately, the new guidelines explain that anyone can be in a successful heterosexual marriage with kids even with "some degree of same-sex attraction." The guidelines, which come from one of the most conservative Catholic leaders in the US, also recommend priests try to break up couples who aren't interested in getting married, which shows they're "lacking in maturity," and claims same-sex relationships will "produce moral confusion in the community." Anyone going against the guidelines should not receive Holy Communion and should be barred from positions of responsibility within the church. The six pages of guidelines are a direct response to Pope Francis' Joy of Love document, which many saw as instructing bishops to be more accepting of "irregular" relationships. But one official with the Philadelphia archdiocese says that document "may not have been as well expressed as it should have been." Chaput's guidelines are meant to clarify it.
response:
In a recent development, Archbishop Charles Chaput of Philadelphia issued new guidelines regarding the Catholic Church's stance on marriage, divorce, and same-sex relationships. According to John Allen, a veteran Vatican journalist, the guidelines are a traditional interpretation of Amoris Laetitia, a papal document that has been subject to various readings and interpretations. This conservative approach has sparked debate among Catholics, with some viewing it as a restrictive interpretation of the document.

The guidelines, which reflect Archbishop Chaput's conservative views, outline the expectations for divorced and remarried couples, same-sex couples, and unmarried couples. For divorced and remarried couples, the guidelines state that they will be welcome to accept Holy Communion, but only if they abstain from sex and live out their relationships like "brother and sister". This condition is likely to be a challenge for many couples, as it requires them to maintain a platonic relationship despite being married.

The guidelines also address same-sex couples, advising priests to help those who are attracted to people of the same sex and find chastity "very difficult". In such cases, priests are encouraged to advise these individuals to frequently seek penance. This approach has been criticized for being overly restrictive and judgmental, as it implies that same-sex attraction is a sin that needs to be atoned for.

Furthermore, the guidelines note that some people with same-sex attraction can still live out a vocation of heterosexual marriage with children, notwithstanding "some degree of same-sex attraction". However, this statement has been met with skepticism by many, as it seems to suggest that same-sex attraction can be overcome through marriage and parenthood.

The implications of these guidelines are far-reaching, as they affect not only individuals but also the broader Catholic community. For those who do not adhere to these guidelines, there may be consequences, such as being denied Holy Communion or facing disciplinary action from the Church. This raises questions about the Church's stance on inclusivity and acceptance, particularly in light of its teachings on love and compassion.

In conclusion, Archbishop Chaput's guidelines represent a traditional and conservative interpretation of the Catholic Church's stance on marriage, divorce, and same-sex relationships. While they may be seen as a restrictive approach by some, they reflect the Archbishop's commitment to upholding Church teachings. However, the guidelines also raise important questions about the Church's approach to inclusivity and acceptance, and whether its teachings on love and compassion are being applied consistently.

But BuzzFeed reports that's not what Austin's mother, Brooke Francey, heard. Lacey "was informed the principal does not agree with boys dressing like girls," she writes on Facebook. Austin, who was told to remove the costume before school even started, says classmates were cool with it and were posing for photos with him. "It wasn't a disruption," a fellow student tells the Press-Enterprise. "Nobody had a problem with it." According to a second Facebook post from Francey, students are passing out flyers encouraging everyone to cross-dress next week to support the LGBT community. "This is a real problem, and as students it is our job to fix this," the flyer states. (These boys were asked to leave school after dressing as Nikki Minaj and Miss America for spirit week.)
response:
In recent years, there have been numerous incidents of public school principals in the United States restricting student expression through dress, often based on personal disapproval. The student, Austin Lacey, was simply trying to have fun and express himself through his costume, but the principal's decision was based on a need to stop a general disruption, according to the school's statement. However, it's worth noting that Austin was not disciplined for the incident and was allowed to complete the school day without any issues.

Restricting student expression through dress is a complex issue, as it often involves a delicate balance between individual freedom and the need to maintain a productive learning environment. In the case of Austin Lacey, his Elsa costume was not causing any harm or disruption, but rather bringing joy to his classmates and adding to the school's spirit day festivities.

The restriction of student expression through dress can also have a negative impact on students' mental health and well-being. When students are forced to conform to certain dress codes or are penalized for expressing themselves through their clothing, it can lead to feelings of frustration, anxiety, and low self-esteem. This can be particularly damaging for students who are already struggling with these issues.

Furthermore, restricting student expression through dress can also have a chilling effect on free speech and creativity. When students are not allowed to express themselves through their clothing, it can send a message that their ideas and opinions are not valued or respected. This can lead to a lack of engagement and participation in school activities, as well as a decrease in creativity and innovation.

In conclusion, restricting student expression through dress is a complex issue that requires careful consideration and balance. While principals have a responsibility to maintain a productive learning environment, they must also respect students' individual freedom and creativity. By allowing students to express themselves through their clothing, schools can foster a positive and inclusive learning environment that promotes creativity, self-expression, and free speech.

report: – A California man named Jack Yufe died this week at age 82, and his life story is so fascinating that the AP likens it to a Hollywood script nobody would believe; the Los Angeles Times draws a comparison to a "tabloid headline." The reason? Yufe was born in Trinidad along with an identical twin brother, but their parents split after 6 months. Yufe grew up as a Jew, even serving a stint in the Israeli navy. Brother Oskar Stohr, meanwhile, went to Germany with his Catholic mom and grew up as a Nazi, becoming a member of the Hitler Youth. They managed to stay in touch and met again at age 21. The weird part? Despite their incredibly different backgrounds, they were alike in nearly every way. They dressed the same (both showed up to their first meeting in a white sports jacket and wire-rimmed glasses), walked the same, wore the same mustache, and had the same temperament and quirks. They both liked to sneeze loudly to scare people as a joke, and "both used to wash their hands before and after going to the toilet," says Nancy Segal, a professor of psychology who studied the pair as part of a well-known study of separated twins at the University of Minnesota. The brothers' story eventually rose to "the center of discussions about nature and nurture," notes the Washington Post. Though the brothers didn't much like each other at first, that changed over the years. When Stohr died of cancer in 1997, a devastated Yufe didn't attend the funeral, however, notes AP. They looked so much alike he was afraid it would upset loved ones. (A survivor of the Nazi death camps' only mass escape also recently died.)

report: – Just days ago, a boat washed ashore in northern Japan. Aboard were eight men who said they were from North Korea. Now, another boat has been found just 45 miles north of the first, and it also held eight—except all are dead. The 23-foot wooden "ghost ship" was discovered Sunday on a beach near Oga. It had no navigational devices and had lost a rotor blade. "I do believe this was a hate crime," he says of the attack, which is believed to have been carried out by a young white man who is still at large. The president of the Charleston NAACP tells the Post and Courier that a survivor says the gunman briefly sat down in the Emanuel AME Church before opening fire on a prayer meeting, but at a news conference this morning, Mullen said the shooter stuck around for almost an hour before the shooting began, the AP reports. Mullen also distributed a surveillance video of a possible suspect and vehicle, and added that the victims were six females and three males. The NAACP chief says the gunman told one woman he was letting her live so she could tell others what happened. "I can assure you that we're going to do everything in our power to find this individual, to lock him up and to make sure he doesn't hurt anyone else." Mayor Joe Riley called the suspect "one hateful person," describing the shooting as "the most dastardly act that one could possibly imagine." In other developments: Helicopters are circling Charleston in the search for the suspect, who's described as a white male, around 21 years old, slender, clean-shaven, and wearing a gray sweatshirt, blue jeans, and Timberland boots, the Guardian reports. The Post and Courier has more on the history of the church, which it calls the "spiritual home to one of the oldest and largest black congregations south of Baltimore," and which many in the city call "Mother Emanuel." report: – The US begins its journey into uncharted territory Friday when Donald Trump takes political office for the first time in his life—starting at the top. He will deliver his inaugural address at 11:51am, according to the AP's timeline, and analysts say it will be one of the most closely watched in history. Advisers say that, like many predecessors, Trump will issue a call for unity and give his vision of "one America." Experts tell NBC News that Trump's unique and repetitive speaking style will drive the message home and maybe even go a little way toward unifying America. "If I keep saying it, it becomes it," says New York University neuroscience professor David Poeppel. In other coverage: The Los Angeles Times reports that Trump has said he looked to the speeches of Ronald Reagan, John F. Kennedy, and Richard Nixon to prepare—and of the three, Nixon might be most relevant. After winning with a minority of the popular vote in the deeply divisive 1968 election, Nixon called on the "better angels of our nature" in his inaugural address, saying America had heard too much inflated and bombastic rhetoric. "We cannot learn from one another until we stop shouting at one another," he said. The San Francisco Chronicle lists five things to look for in Trump's address, including efforts to reassure foreign leaders. Ad-libs are also a strong possibility, though analysts say trying to wing it could be a big mistake. The speech was largely written by incoming senior White House adviser Stephen Miller, Politico reports in its guide to inaugural events, which includes viewing tips and the order of the ceremony. The Washington Post looks at the many demonstrations that will be taking place across the capital on Friday, including a few pro-Trump events, as well as numerous "counterinaugural" protests. The "Let America Hear Us, Roar for Trump" group will be sharing Dupont Circle with a pro-marijuana group that plans to hand out 4,200 joints. Time takes a look back at every Inauguration Day in US history, and at what every president had to say on the occasion. The Times of London reports on the "security nightmare" posed by Trump's first ride in the presidential limousine, which will take him past tens of thousands of people between the Capitol and the White House. Many will be watching to see whether he chooses to walk part of the way as predecessors including Obama did. The New York Times speaks to five Trump voters from very different backgrounds to find out why they traveled to DC for the inauguration. Protests are taking place in cities across the world, but in Melania Trump's hometown in Slovenia, they're getting ready for a huge party, TMZ reports. The Atlantic reports that there will apparently be no poetry on the agenda, which is more a sign of the partisan divide than a break with tradition.

On January 20, 2017, Donald Trump took the oath of office as the 45th President of the United States, marking the beginning of a new era in American politics. The day was filled with excitement and anticipation as Trump's supporters and detractors alike gathered to witness the historic event. Trump's inaugural address, written by Stephen Miller, was a significant aspect of the day's proceedings, and it set the tone for his presidency. In his speech, Trump emphasized the need for unity and called for Americans to come together to address the country's structural problems. However, not everyone was pleased with Trump's inaugural address. Protests erupted across the country, with thousands of people taking to the streets to express their opposition to Trump's presidency. The demonstrations were largely peaceful, but some turned violent, resulting in clashes between protesters and law enforcement. The security measures in place were robust, with thousands of National Guard troops deployed to maintain order and ensure the safety of the attendees. Despite the protests, Trump's supporters remained defiant, waving flags and cheering as he took the oath of office.

The world watched with bated breath as Trump took the reins of power, with many countries expressing their concern over his policies and rhetoric. In Europe, there were fears that Trump's presidency would mark a shift away from traditional alliances and towards a more isolationist approach. In Asia, there were concerns about Trump's stance on trade and his plans to renegotiate international agreements. Despite these concerns, Trump's inauguration was widely covered in the media, with many outlets broadcasting live coverage of the event.

In his inaugural address, Trump also paid tribute to the country's founding fathers, hailing them as heroes who had fought for freedom and democracy. He also emphasized the need for Americans to come together and work towards a common goal, saying "We will bring back our jobs. We will bring back our borders. We will bring back our wealth. And we will bring back our dreams". Trump's speech was met with a mixed reaction, with some praising his message of unity and others criticizing his divisive rhetoric.

Overall, Trump's Inauguration Day was a significant event that marked the beginning of a new era in American politics. The day was filled with excitement and anticipation, but also with protests and concerns from across the country and the world. As Trump looked out over the crowd, he knew that he had a long and challenging road ahead of him, but he was determined to make America great again.

report: – To all the new parents struggling to feed their newborn every two to three hours, imagine having to do it every hour—for years. Such is reality for the Torti family in Tennessee, whose son, Owen, now 23 months, was diagnosed with the rare metabolic disorder LCHAD (long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase) as an infant. Because his body doesn't break down certain foods into energy, Owen is at risk of his body breaking down his muscles for energy if he goes without food for more than an hour, reports ABC News. "He wants to act like a normal 2-year-old and he wants to go and play and run around as long as the other 2-year-olds," mom Kayla Torti says. "Unfortunately, we have to have him sit down and take little breaks. He doesn't know how to pace himself." LCHAD, which was first diagnosed in the 1990s, is so rare it only affects one in every 100,000 newborns and wasn't even on newborn screening tests until six years ago, reports WKRN Nashville. To help with medical bills, two teams recently ran the Ragnar Relay through Tennessee wearing "All in for Owen" shirts and raised $15,000. Owen was born nine weeks premature, according to the family's YouCaring page, and has been hospitalized 12 times in 20 months, typically when a metabolic breakdown causes breathing problems and seizures. If not treated, he could slip into a coma and even die. With the constant eating, his mother says he's developed an oral aversion to food and is on a special medical formula called Lipistart, administered largely through a feeding tube. The Tortis have a 25% chance of having a second child with the same disorder. (These parents are losing both their sons to a rare brain disease.)

topic: Write a report on creative, unusual, and humorous ways that families have used obituaries to celebrate the lives and memories of deceased loved ones. Please provide examples of specific obituaries that stand out for their unique tone, anecdotes, or advice.
questions: What is the name of the 85-year-old woman from Wisconsin whose obituary was featured by The AV Club?
According to Mary "Pink" Mullaney's family, what is a creative way to use old pantyhose?
What is a unique way to get picky-eating children to eat vegetables, as suggested by Mary "Pink" Mullaney?
What is Mary "Pink" Mullaney's advice on how to treat people you might not like?
How did Mary "Pink" Mullaney suggest making the car "dance" while driving?
What is a creative way to deal with a possum that has taken up residence in your shed, according to Mary "Pink" Mullaney?
Why did Mary "Pink" Mullaney's family include lessons and quotes from her in her obituary?

report: – The AV Club loves the obituary for an 85-year-old woman in Wisconsin named Mary "Pink" Mullaney. Why? Maybe because her family filled it with lessons imparted by Mullaney in life, including, “Never throw away old pantyhose. Use the old ones to tie gutters, child-proof cabinets, tie toilet flappers, or hang Christmas ornaments.” Explains Mullaney's daughter to WAOW: "We said, 'How can we be like her and carry her pinkness across?'" Some other gems: "Go to a nursing home and kiss everyone." "Put picky-eating children in the box at the bottom of the laundry chute, tell them they are hungry lions in a cage, and feed them veggies through the slats." "Never say mean things about anybody; they are 'poor souls to pray for.'" "Make the car dance by lightly tapping the brakes to the beat of the song on the radio." "If a possum takes up residence in your shed, grab a barbecue brush to coax him out. If he doesn't leave, brush him for twenty minutes and let him stay." Read the full obituary here. Or read a moving, self-written obit from a Seattle writer.
response:
A unique approach to celebrating the lives of deceased loved ones has emerged in the form of creative and humorous obituaries. These death announcements not only pay tribute to the deceased but also leave behind a legacy of life lessons and anecdotes that can inspire and entertain. Take the obituary of Mary Agnes Mullaney, better known as "Pink," a remarkable Milwaukee woman who passed away earlier this week. Her family knew a normal obituary wouldn't suffice for an extraordinary woman, so they decided to write a unique death announcement that showcased her personality and values. The result is a colorful and inspiring tribute to Pink's life, which includes quotes and anecdotes that reflect her kindness, generosity, and compassion. For instance, "Go to church with a chicken sandwich in your purse. Give the chicken sandwich to your homeless friend after mass". This quote, among many others, highlights Pink's dedication to helping others, regardless of their background or circumstances.

The obituary of Mary A. "Pink" Mullaney is a standout example of a creative and humorous obituary that not only celebrates the life of the deceased but also provides life lessons and anecdotes that can inspire and entertain. The obituary begins with a humorous remark, "If you're about to throw away an old pair of pantyhose, stop," and only gets more amazing and oddly inspirational from there. The full obituary is a treasure trove of life lessons and humorous anecdotes, including believing a hitchhiker who claims to be a landscaper named 'Peat Moss,' taking magazines to the doctor's office for others to enjoy, and putting picky-eating children in a laundry chute to feed them veggies. These anecdotes not only showcase Pink's quirky personality but also provide a glimpse into her values and priorities.

The use of obituaries as a means of celebrating the lives of deceased loved ones is a unique and creative way to honor their memory. It allows families to share their loved one's personality, values, and legacy with a wider audience, providing a sense of comfort and closure for those who are grieving. As seen in the obituary of Mary Agnes Mullaney, a creative and humorous approach can not only inspire and entertain but also provide a lasting tribute to a life well lived. In conclusion, the use of creative and humorous obituaries is a wonderful way to celebrate the lives of deceased loved ones, leaving behind a legacy of life lessons and anecdotes that can inspire and entertain for generations to come.

topic: Provide an update on the status of the use of solitary confinement in California state prisons, including any changes in policy or practice and any court actions or settlements related to the issue.
questions: What has California agreed to stop using as a means of controlling prison gangs?
Who were the two inmates who originally filed the class-action federal lawsuit in 2009?
What is the expected outcome for many of the prisoners who were previously held in solitary confinement?
What type of cells were often used to segregate prisoners, and what were their living conditions like?
What are the new "restrictive custody units" intended for, and what privileges will they allow prisoners?
What is the union that represents most prison guards concerned about, regarding the state's decision?
How many inmates are covered in the class-action federal lawsuit?
What was the duration of solitary confinement for hundreds of prisoners under California's previous policy?
What activities or privileges will prisoners in the new "restrictive custody units" have access to?
What is the potential risk, according to the prison guards' union, if the state returns to the prison environment of the '70s and '80s?
report: – Thousands of inmates will soon be moved out of solitary confinement in California, after years of court battles and hunger strikes against the controversial practice. The state's decision was revealed in a legal settlement filed today—which still must be accepted by the court—with a group of inmates who have been isolated at Pelican Bay State Prison for 10 years or more, the Los Angeles Times reports. The settlement applies to a class-action federal lawsuit covering almost 3,000 inmates, a lawsuit originally filed in 2009 by Todd Ashker and Danny Troxell, two murderers serving sentences in Pelican Bay. California has agreed to stop using solitary confinement as a means of controlling prison gangs; instead, the most dangerous prisoners will be held in a group setting and will have many of the same privileges as other inmates. As the AP notes, California's previously unlimited isolation of gang leaders had been used to keep hundreds of prisoners segregated (often in soundproofed, windowless cells of just 80 square feet, for all but an hour and a half per day, with no access to visitors, communication, or even reading materials) for 10 years or more. Now, California will release many of the affected prisoners back into the general prison population and will limit the amount of time prisoners can spend in isolation. New "restrictive custody units" will be used for inmates who commit new crimes while in prison, refuse to participate in rehab, or who may be in danger from other inmates, but those units will allow prisoners more personal contact and other privileges. The union that represents most prison guards has expressed safety concerns, with the spokesperson noting that the state could "return to the prison environment of the '70s and '80s, when inmate-on-inmate homicides were at the highest levels and staff were killed."
response:
The use of solitary confinement in California state prisons has undergone significant changes in recent years. As reported by, the state has agreed to settle a class-action federal lawsuit on behalf of nearly 3,000 California inmates held in segregation statewide. The lawsuit, which was initially filed in 2009 by two killers serving time in the security housing unit at Pelican Bay, contended that isolating inmates in 80-square-foot cells for all but about 90 minutes each day amounts to cruel and unusual punishment. The settlement, which aims to limit the length of time inmates can spend in isolation, is a significant step towards addressing the concerns raised by the lawsuit.

In addition to the settlement, California has also agreed to end its unlimited isolation of imprisoned gang leaders. According to Corrections and Rehabilitation Secretary Jeffrey Beard, the new policy will restrict the practice of locking gang members in soundproofed, windowless cells solely to keep them from directing illegal activities by gang members. Instead, inmates will only be segregated if they commit new crimes behind bars. This change in policy reflects a shift towards a more rehabilitative approach, one that relies less on segregation and more on rehabilitation programs.

The new policy and settlement are a result of ongoing efforts to reform the use of solitary confinement in California state prisons. As reported by, the settlement will create restrictive custody units for inmates who refuse to participate in rehabilitation programs or keep breaking prison rules. This move is seen as a way to provide inmates with the support and resources they need to rehabilitate, rather than simply isolating them. The state's decision to end unlimited isolation of imprisoned gang leaders also reflects a recognition that segregation is not an effective way to manage problematic inmates.

Court actions and settlements related to the issue of solitary confinement in California state prisons have been ongoing for several years. In addition to the settlement mentioned above, there have been several other lawsuits and court decisions related to the use of solitary confinement in California prisons. For example, in 2015, a federal judge ruled that California's use of solitary confinement on juveniles was unconstitutional. The ruling was a significant victory for advocates of prison reform, who have long argued that solitary confinement is particularly harmful for young people.

Overall, the changes in policy and practice related to solitary confinement in California state prisons reflect a growing recognition of the need to reform the use of isolation in prisons. As the state continues to grapple with the issue, it is likely that we will see further changes and reforms in the coming years.

report: – The Vatican is doubling down on its anti-gay marriage stance, which today had the unlikely result of a group of women ripping their shirts off as Pope Benedict gave his Sunday address, reports Reuters. Four members of the Ukrainian Femen group screamed "homophobes, shut up!" and shed their shirts to reveal slogans including "In Gay We Trust," but were quickly carted away by police. The Pope didn't appear to notice. "Today we are here to protest against homophobia," one of the women tells the AP. The women were responding to a Vatican editorial in response to a gay adoption case. It read: "The human is the masculine and the feminine ... the monogamous family is the ideal place to learn the meaning of human relations and is the environment where the best form of growth is possible."
response:
In recent months, the Vatican has taken a more vocal stance against gay marriage, with Pope Benedict reaffirming the Church's opposition to the institution. According to Pope Benedict, heterosexual marriage has an indispensable role in society, emphasizing the importance of traditional family values. This stance was recently evident in the reaction to a protest by four women from the Ukrainian Femen group, who appeared topless in St. Peter's Square during the pope's weekly address, bearing the slogans "In Gay we Trust" on their bodies. The protesters were met with anger from pilgrims, with one woman even hitting them with an umbrella and calling them "diabolical". The Italian police eventually intervened and pulled the protesters away from the crowd, highlighting the tension surrounding the issue.

Furthermore, the Vatican has reiterated its opposition to gay adoption, following a recent Italian court ruling that rejected a father's appeal to prevent his son from living with his mother and her female partner. The Court of Cassation ruled that it was "mere prejudice" to assume that living with a homosexual couple could be detrimental for a child's development. However, the Vatican's newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, responded with an editorial that sought to downplay the ruling, arguing that while children can grow up in difficult circumstances without a mother or father, these situations should not be intentionally created. The editorial reaffirmed the Vatican's view that the traditional family unit, with a mother and father, is the ideal environment for a child's growth and development.

The Vatican's stance on gay marriage and adoption has been met with criticism from some quarters, with protesters taking to the streets to express their dissent. The protest by the four women from the Ukrainian Femen group was just one example of the strong reaction against the Vatican's stance. While the Vatican maintains that its opposition to gay marriage and adoption is based on its commitment to traditional family values, many see this as a form of discrimination against the LGBTQ+ community. As the debate surrounding gay marriage and adoption continues, it remains to be seen how the Vatican will respond to the changing social landscape.

In conclusion, the Vatican's recent statements and actions against gay marriage and adoption have sparked controversy and debate. While the Church maintains its opposition to these institutions, many see this as a form of discrimination against the LGBTQ+ community. As the world becomes increasingly accepting of diverse family structures, it will be interesting to see how the Vatican responds to these changes in the future.

report: – A free Willie Nelson concert in the heart of the Lone Star State seems like something that would attract fans of all political stripes, but there's a good chance the Sept. 29 event will feature a largely left-leaning crowd. That's because the country crooner is headlining a "Turn Out for Texas" rally in Austin for Beto O'Rourke, the Democratic challenger to GOP Sen. Ted Cruz, and many of Nelson's fans aren't happy about it, KTRK reports. Per Austin360, it's "the first public concert Nelson has held for a political candidate," the singer's publicist says in a release, though Rolling Stone notes he's put on private concerts for politicians in the past. "My wife Annie and I have met and spoken with Beto and we share his concern for the direction things are headed," Nelson says in the release. "Beto embodies what is special about Texas, an energy and an integrity that is completely genuine." The site notes Nelson even brought O'Rourke out on stage during his Fourth of July concert. None of this pleases Nelson's more conservative fans, who see his ties to O'Rourke as a "breaking point," per the Washington Post. "I am certain you've lost your mind," one commenter wrote on Nelson's Facebook page, while another noted: "Willie's position is proof positive that marijuana use over time kills brain cells." Still others are dumping already purchased tickets to future Nelson shows. Many, however, applauded Nelson's decision. "So glad you are involved in this good cause. I have always been a fan, and am now a bigger fan," noted one well-liked post. The Post notes Nelson has long been politically active, throwing his support behind Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton, and Bernie Sanders, and advocating for pot legalization, gay marriage, and the environment.

topic: For the missing AirAsia Flight 8501, please provide a report comparing and contrasting the disappearance of this flight to that of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
questions: What is the primary difference between the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and AirAsia Flight 8501 in terms of onboard systems?
What was the weather condition like when AirAsia Flight 8501 disappeared?
What was the last communication between the AirAsia pilot and air traffic control?
How much flying experience did the pilot of Flight 370 have compared to the combined experience of Flight 8501's pilot and co-pilot?
Why did neither Flight 370 nor Flight 8501 issue an emergency distress call?
What was the major difference between the search areas for Flight 370 and Flight 8501?
How does the search area for Flight 8501 differ from the Indian Ocean in terms of depth?
What factor contributed to the lack of immediate communication from the pilots of both flights during emergencies?
How does the radar coverage in the search area for Flight 8501 compare to that in the search area for Flight 370?
What was the response of the AirAsia pilot to the stormy weather encountered by Flight 8501?
report: – The disappearance of another jet in Southeast Asia while the fate of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 remains a mystery comes as a shock to the aviation world, but experts stress that the two cases are very different. The New York Times runs through some of the differences with AirAsia Flight 8501: Unlike with Flight 370, there has been no sign that anybody on Flight 8501 intentionally disabled any onboard systems, meaning that investigators should have the normal automatic transmissions from the flight to help the search. Flight 370 disappeared on a clear night, while Flight 8501 was believed to have encountered stormy weather, with weather agencies having reported lightning strikes along its route. The AirAsia pilot's last communication with air traffic control was a request "to avoid clouds by turning left and going higher to 38,000 feet." Flight 370's pilot was very experienced, with more than 18,000 hours of flying time, while the combined experience of Flight 8501's pilot and co-pilot is believed to be less than half that. Neither Flight 370 nor Flight 8501 issued an emergency distress call, but, as the AP notes, "pilots are trained to focus first on the emergency at hand and then communicate only when free," and there's no sign that the AirAsia flight diverted sharply from its intended course the way the Malaysia Airlines flight did. Another major difference is the search area for Flight 8501, which is much smaller and shallower than the vast area that has been searched for Flight 370. "We are not talking about the deep Indian Ocean here," says CNN aviation correspondent Richard Quest. "We are talking about congested airspace around Southeast Asia. There will be much better radar coverage. There's certainly better air traffic control coverage."
response:
The disappearance of AirAsia Flight 8501 has sparked a flurry of speculation, with several possibilities being considered. One theory is that the plane experienced some type of catastrophic metal fatigue caused by the cycle of pressurization and depressurization associated with each takeoff and landing cycle. Although the plane is only 6 years old, it had accumulated 13,600 takeoffs and landings, many of which occurred in a humid climate, which speeds corrosion. However, this theory is unlikely because metal fatigue is rare in planes of this age. Another possibility is that the plane encountered bad weather, such as severe thunderstorms, which could have been a factor in its disappearance. The plane was in the safest part of flight, with only 10 percent of fatal crashes occurring during cruise elevation. However, passing through bad weather could have been a cause of the disappearance. It's also possible that the plane experienced a mechanical failure, although there's no evidence to support this theory.

In contrast to the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, the search for AirAsia Flight 8501 is expected to be much easier. Unlike the deep Indian Ocean where MH370 went missing, the search area for Flight 8501 is congested airspace around Southeast Asia, which will provide better radar coverage and air traffic control coverage. This is a significant difference, as searchers have yet to find any remains of Flight 370, which officials believe went down in the southern Indian Ocean after mysteriously flying thousands of kilometers away from its planned route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. The loss of contact with the plane comes nearly 10 months after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370. While both incidents are tragic, the search for AirAsia Flight 8501 is expected to be less challenging due to the better radar coverage and air traffic control coverage in the search area.

In conclusion, the disappearance of AirAsia Flight 8501 has raised several possibilities, including metal fatigue, bad weather, and mechanical failure. However, the search for the plane is expected to be much easier than the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 due to the congested airspace around Southeast Asia. While both incidents are tragic, the difference in search conditions highlights the complexities of air travel and the need for continued vigilance and improvement in safety measures. Ultimately, the cause of the disappearance of AirAsia Flight 8501 will likely be determined through a thorough investigation, which will provide valuable insights into the incident. Citing and as examples, the investigation will aim to identify the root cause of the disappearance and implement measures to prevent similar incidents in the future.

topic: Provide a report on the recent decision by the Capitol Hill Standing Committee of Correspondents regarding Breitbart's application for permanent congressional press credentials.
questions: What is the current status of Breitbart's temporary press credentials to cover Congress?
What is the main concern of the Capitol Hill Standing Committee of Correspondents regarding Breitbart?
Who used to run the Government Accountability Institute, which is funded by a major Republican donor?
What is one of the requirements for news outlets to gain congressional access, according to the committee?

What is the committee's reason for not considering Breitbart's application for permanent credentials?
What is the deadline for Breitbart's temporary press credentials?
Who is the major Republican donor funding the Government Accountability Institute?
What is the condition for Breitbart to reapply for congressional access?
What is the role of the secretary for the Capitol Hill Standing Committee of Correspondents?
report: – Breitbart's temporary press credentials to cover Congress won't be extended, and its application for permanent credentials is no longer being considered, Politico reports. The secretary for the Capitol Hill Standing Committee of Correspondents, which oversees credentialing, tells USA Today that Breitbart simply is "not ready." The committee only gives congressional access to news outlets it considers "legitimate." Its concern about Breitbart is that several editors are also employed by the Government Accountability Institute, which Steve Bannon used to run and which is funded by a major Republican donor. It also takes issue with Breitbart's lack of office space. Breitbart's temporary credentials expire at the end of May. It can reapply for access if it addresses the committee's concerns.
response:
The recent decision by the Capitol Hill Standing Committee of Correspondents to table Breitbart News' application for permanent congressional press credentials has left the news outlet in a precarious position. According to Billy House, chairman of the Standing Committee, the ongoing questions about Breitbart's editorial independence made it impossible for the committee to approve the group's application. This decision was not taken lightly, as Breitbart had applied to become a credentialed member of the Senate Daily Press Gallery, joining other mainstream news outlets such as The New York Times and USA TODAY. However, the committee's concerns about Breitbart's independence were not alleviated by CEO Larry Solov's appeal to approve individual reporters instead of the whole organization.

One of the main concerns raised by the committee was the fact that several top editors at Breitbart News were also employed by the Government Accountability Institute, a non-profit organization run by Steve Bannon, Breitbart's former CEO. This raised questions about the organization's ability to maintain editorial independence, as Bannon's ties to the Mercer family, who fund both Breitbart News and the Government Accountability Institute, were seen as a potential conflict of interest. Furthermore, Solov's admission that he still has not found a suitable Washington office for Breitbart News, despite the fact that the building he operated out of was not zoned for commercial activity, only added to the committee's concerns.

The Standing Committee's decision to table Breitbart's application was not without precedent. In the past, the committee has been cautious in its approach to granting press credentials to new organizations, particularly those with ties to lobbying or paid advocacy. The committee's rules state that reporters must not be engaged in any lobbying or paid advocacy work, and will not do so while a member of the Daily Press Galleries. In this case, the committee felt that Breitbart News did not meet these criteria, and therefore could not be granted permanent press credentials.

While this decision may be seen as a setback for Breitbart News, it is not a permanent one. According to Joe Morton, secretary of the Standing Committee, Breitbart could ultimately qualify for press credentials if the organization gets better established and demonstrates its ability to maintain editorial independence. Until then, the news outlet will have to rely on its temporary credentials, which will expire at the end of May. The Standing Committee's decision serves as a reminder of the importance of maintaining editorial independence and adhering to the rules and guidelines set forth by the committee. It also highlights the challenges faced by new organizations seeking to establish themselves as credible news sources in the world of Capitol Hill journalism. topic: Write a report on the current status of the ABC Conjecture in mathematics, a long-standing problem in number theory, including any recent attempts to prove or disprove the conjecture, and any relevant background information on the problem itself.
questions: What is the ABC conjecture and why is it considered a big problem in the world of math?
Who is Shinichi Mochizuki and what is his claim related to the ABC conjecture?
Why is it difficult for mathematicians to understand Mochizuki's proof of the ABC conjecture?
What is the Inter-Universal Teichmuller Theory and why is it necessary to master it to understand Mochizuki's proof?
How long has Mochizuki's proof been in a state of "math limbo" and what efforts have been made to clarify it?
What is the significance of the ABC conjecture and why is its proof considered a major milestone?
Can you explain the concept of "smooth numbers" in number theory and how it relates to the ABC conjecture?
What is the general reaction of mathematicians to Mochizuki's proof, and why is it not being widely accepted or rejected?
Who is Minhyong Kim and what is his opinion on the current state of Mochizuki's proof?
What is the potential impact of the ABC conjecture's proof on our understanding of the "nature of numbers"?
report: – A Japanese mathematician swears he's solved one of the biggest problems in the world of math. The problem is, nobody, not even fellow mathematicians of the highest caliber, can understand Shinichi Mochizuki's proof of something called the ABC conjecture, reports New Scientist. It doesn't help that the proof itself is 500 pages long or that Mochizuki developed his own set of mathematical principles called the Inter-Universal Teichmuller Theory that must be mastered first. (Those who don't are "simply not qualified" to weigh in, says Mochizuki.) Mathematicians aren't saying that Mochizuki's resolution of the theory is wrong, but they're not saying it's right, either. As a result, it's been in a kind of math limbo since 2012, despite attempts by the Kyoto University professor as recently as last month to shed light on it. As for the ABC conjecture, it's a longstanding math problem that also happens to be "deceptively complicated," explains ZME Science. "It roughly states that three numbers a, b, and c, which have no common factor and satisfy a + b = c cannot be too smooth. ... In number theory, a smooth number is an integer which factors completely into small prime numbers." Got that? The upshot, according to both sites, is that the theory raises fundamental questions about the "nature of numbers," and thus its proof would be a major milestone. "It's a bit disappointing that no one has come out and said it's right or wrong," says Oxford professor Minhyong Kim. (Elsewhere, a beating seems to have turned this man into a math whiz.)
response:
The ABC Conjecture, a fundamental problem in number theory, has been a subject of intense study for mathematicians for centuries. Despite its deceptively simple statement, the conjecture poses deep questions about the nature of numbers and has far-reaching implications for various areas of mathematics. The conjecture, roughly stated as a + b = c, where a, b, and c have no common factor, has been a long-standing mystery in mathematics, with many mathematicians attempting to prove or disprove it over the years.

One of the most significant recent attempts to prove the ABC conjecture was made by Shinichi Mochizuki, a mathematician at Kyoto University, Japan. In 2012, Mochizuki posted a 500-page paper online that claimed to solve the puzzle, but it required a dense framework of new mathematics called "Inter-universal Teichmüller Theory" that even experienced mathematicians found difficult to follow. Mochizuki's proof, while groundbreaking, has been met with skepticism by the mathematical community, with many mathematicians questioning the correctness of his proof. Minhyong Kim of the University of Oxford notes that while Mochizuki is a highly respected mathematician, no one has been able to give a definitive answer on whether the proof is correct.

The situation has led to comparisons with Grigori Perelman, a mathematician who refused to engage with the mathematical community and ultimately turned down a $1 million prize for his solution to the Poincaré conjecture. Mochizuki's seeming reticence to explain his work in a more standard way has sparked debate, with some mathematicians suggesting that he should simplify his notes or lecture abroad to facilitate understanding. For now, the proof remains in limbo, leaving the mathematical community in a "curious state." The ABC conjecture's complexity and Mochizuki's unorthodox approach have made it difficult for mathematicians to verify his proof, and the community remains uncertain about the correctness of his solution.

The ABC conjecture itself is deceptively complicated, and its statement roughly captures the intuitive sense that triples of numbers which satisfy a linear relation, and which are divisible by high perfect powers, are rare. The conjecture has far-reaching implications for various areas of mathematics, including number theory, algebra, and geometry. While Mochizuki's proof has been met with skepticism, it has also sparked a new wave of interest in the conjecture, with many mathematicians attempting to understand and verify his work. Ultimately, the resolution of the ABC conjecture will depend on the mathematical community's ability to understand and verify Mochizuki's proof, or to come up with an alternative solution.

In conclusion, the ABC Conjecture remains a long-standing problem in number theory, with significant implications for various areas of mathematics. Shinichi Mochizuki's attempt to prove the conjecture has sparked debate and uncertainty, but it has also sparked a new wave of interest in the problem. The resolution of the conjecture will depend on the mathematical community's ability to understand and verify Mochizuki's proof, or to come up with an alternative solution. The ABC conjecture's complexity and Mochizuki's unorthodox approach have made it a challenging problem to solve, but it has also made it a fascinating and intriguing puzzle for mathematicians to tackle.

What is the orbital period of Kepler 78b around its host star?
How did astronomers initially discover Kepler 78b?
How far is Kepler 78b from Earth?
Why is the formation of Kepler 78b considered an enigma?
What is the composition of Kepler 78b similar to?
What conclusion can be drawn from the discovery of Kepler 78b regarding other Earth-like planets?
report: – Astronomers have discovered a planet where a certain red guy with horns could make himself right at home. It's a planet much like our own Earth—about the same size, with the same mixture of rock and iron, and it orbits a star like our sun—except that Kepler 78b is an infernal ball of fire. Located less than a million miles from its host star—that's 1% of the distance between Earth and our sun—its temperature ranges between 3,500 and 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit. That's "well above the temperature where rock melts," an astronomer tells the New York Times. "This is probably one of the most hellish planets that have been discovered yet." At 400 light-years from Earth, the exoplanet was first spotted by the Kepler spacecraft but astronomers on Earth took a closer look at its light frequency to discover its orbit and mass. The findings, published in two studies in Nature, show a planet that tightly orbits its sun—which from the surface would look 80 times larger than our sun—in just eight and a half hours. Adds an expert, per LiveScience: "This planet is an enigma. It couldn't have formed in place because you can't form a planet inside a star." But while astronomers are baffled as to how the planet got there, they're fairly certain it shows friendlier Earthlike planets are still out there.
response:
Kepler 78b, a fascinating exoplanet, has garnered significant attention among astronomers due to its striking resemblance to Earth in terms of size and composition. With a diameter of approximately 20% larger than Earth's and a mass of about 80% more massive, Kepler 78b presents a unique opportunity to study a planet that, in many respects, is the most like our own. The planet's density, remarkably close to that of Earth, further reinforces its Earth-like nature, with an estimated density of around 5.6 grams per cubic centimeter. Kepler 78b orbits a G-type star, similar to our Sun, in the constellation Cygnus, approximately 400 light-years from Earth. The planet's orbital period is approximately 8.5 hours, which is significantly shorter than Earth's 24-hour day.

The discovery of Kepler 78b was made possible by the Kepler space telescope, a pioneering mission launched by NASA in March 2009. Employing the radial velocity technique, two research teams led by Andrew Howard and Francesco Pepe successfully detected the planet's mass and density. This method measures the subtle wobble in a host star's light caused by the gravitational pull of an orbiting planet, providing valuable insights into the planet's characteristics. The results of these studies suggest that Kepler 78b has a rocky interior and an iron core, similar to Earth's composition.

The surface temperature of Kepler 78b is estimated to be around 3,680 degrees Fahrenheit (2,000 degrees Celsius), making it inhospitable to life as we know it. This extreme temperature is a result of the planet's close proximity to its host star, which is likely to be a strong source of heat. Despite its inhospitable environment, Kepler 78b remains an intriguing subject of study, offering scientists a unique opportunity to explore the properties of a planet that is, in many respects, the most like Earth discovered outside our solar system.

In conclusion, Kepler 78b is a remarkable exoplanet that shares many characteristics with Earth, making it an essential target for further research and study. Its unique features, such as its Earth-like composition and rocky interior, make it an attractive subject for scientists seeking to understand the properties of planets beyond our solar system. The discovery of Kepler 78b has also highlighted the importance of missions like the Kepler space telescope, which continue to push the boundaries of our knowledge about the universe and its many mysteries.
